Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Polymer Brush-like Architecture for Temperature Dependent Cell Release and Attachment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is designed to offer two uniquely tailored thermoresponsive surfaces for the attachment and release of weakly and strongly adherent cells. The commercially available surfaces are highly crosslinked hydrogels that do not work well with either strongly or weakly adherent cells. The goal is to transform the current thermoresponsive cell culture technology by providing novel polymer brush-like architectures to the culture surface to reduce protein adsorption, and allow efficient hydration to release the strongly adherent cells. Moreover, addition of functionalities to polymer brush-like architectures will increase the adhesive strength of the surfaces for weakly adherent cells. Major research objectives of this proposal include: 1) Synthesis of photoreactive thermoresponsive brush architectures for strongly adherent cells 2) Synthesis of functionalized brush architectures for weakly adherent cells and 3) Develop coatings in a variety of different cultureware not presently available in market due to the method used. The goal is 90% release of strongly adherent cells within 30 minutes at room temperature and 80% attachment of weakly adherent cells.

The broader impact /commercial potential of this project will be the generation of functional cells or cell sheets. The generation of physiologically active functional cells is often the roadblock in technology development. For example, cells recovered from conventional growth surfaces are released using digestive enzymes and chemicals such as Trypsin and EDTA, which alter signal transduction pathways and affect overall cell viability. Thermoresponsive cell cultureware involving the use of Poly N-isopropylacrylamide (PNIPAAm) obviates the use of digestive enzymes; however, major roadblocks with the use of thermoresponsive cultureware remain. The commercially available thermoresponsive plates work well with several cell lines, but do not work well with strongly adherent or weakly adherent cell types, and are available only in multiwell formats. This Phase I grant will develop a new generation of thermoresponsive cell cultureware that could gain wide market acceptance, and become an enabling technology. The process uses simple equipment, is manufacture-friendly, cost-effective, and is available in formats needed for tissue engineering and high-throughput applications. Thus, clinical applications of cell types that were previously considered impossible may be realized, and cell therapy, drug discovery, and tissue engineering applications may proceed at an accelerated pace.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project has created uniquely tailored brush polymer coatings on a variety of cell cultureware (multiwell plates and flasks) for thermo-responsive cell attachment and release. The polymer brush coatings were developed to create two distinct cell culture surfaces: (1)ISurBind surface for the weakly adherent cell types and (2) ISurSpeed surface optimized for the attachment and release of strongly adherent cells. The other competitive and commercially available thermo-responsive surface is a highly crosslinked hydrogel which do not work for the weakly or strongly adherent cells without any manipulations. Moreover, these surfaces are available only in multiwell plate formats due to the coating technology limitation.

Technical objectives of the Phase I proposal were as follows

  1. Create brush polymer architectures of thermo-responsive polymers for the release of strongly adherent cells.
  2. Synthesize functionalized thermo-responsive polymers to provide mat and brush architectures for the culture of weakly adherent cells.
  3. Develop coatings to provide polymer brush architectures in cell cultureware of different configurations such as plates and flasks.
  4. Determine the ability of functionalized surfaces to anchor mature cell sheets.

The project successfully achieved all of the technical objectives with the following results

  1. Highly desirable brush polymer architectures were created to make ISurSpeed surfaces which released the strongly adherent adult stem cells within 30 minutes of incubation at room temperature.
  2. Successful synthesis of functionalized thermo-responsive polymers to create ISurBind surfaces for the attachment of weakly adherent cell types. The addition of functional groups to the polymer brushes increased the adhesive strength of the substrates for weakly adherent cell types without compromising the detachment time.
  3. The ISurSpeed and ISurBind architectures worked equally well in multiwell plates and flasks.

The novel polymer brush architectures on the culture surface reduced protein adsorption and allowed efficient hydration to release the strongly adherent cells. Addition of functionalities to polymer brush architectures increased the adhesive strength of the surfaces for the culture of weakly adherent cell types and for anchoring mature cell sheets needed for cell sheet engineering applications. Thus, with the completion of this project, ISurTec will offer to the market a complete array of cell cultureware, thereby expanding the thermo-responsive technology to a wide variety of industrial, pharmaceutical and tissue engineering applications.

We are confident that the manufacture friendly process to create novel brush polymer thermo-responsive surfaces can be successfully scaled up in the Phase II part of the project. In addition, apart from standard thermo-responsive cell cultureware (flasks, multiwell plates and inserts), ISurTec will also develop thermo-resonsive microcarriers and 3D scaffolds, a current unmet need in the market.

In summary, the technical development allows efficient thermo-responsive cell attachment and release of a broad variety of cell types. The two specialized thermo-responsive surfaces will meet the non-invasive cell culture needs of a variety of applications in the fields of tissue engineering, cell therapy and drug discovery. Thus, clinical and pharmaceutical applications of cell types which were previously considered impossible, can be realized. Future developments in cell therapy and stem cell technologies combined with a full toolbox of thermo-responsive formats tailored for different types of cells, promises great benefits for human health and welfare.

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2014
Modified by: Tahmina Naqvi

The polymer brush coatings were developed to create two distinct cell culture surfaces: (1)ISurBind surface for the weakly adherent cell types and (2) ISurSpeed surface optimized for the attachment and release of strongly adherent cells. The other competitive and commercially available thermo-responsive surface is a highly crosslinked hydrogel which do not work for the weakly or strongly adherent cells without any manipulations. Technical objectives of the Phase I proposal were as follows Create brush polymer architectures of thermo-responsive polymers for the release of strongly adherent cells. Synthesize functionalized thermo-responsive polymers to provide mat and brush architectures for the culture of weakly adherent cells. Develop coatings to provide polymer brush architectures in cell cultureware of different configurations such as plates and flasks. Determine the ability of functionalized surfaces to anchor mature cell sheets. The project successfully achieved all of the technical objectives with the following results Highly desirable brush polymer architectures were created to make ISurSpeed surfaces which released the strongly adherent adult stem cells within 30 minutes of incubation at room temperature. Successful synthesis of functionalized thermo-responsive polymers to create ISurBind surfaces for the attachment of weakly adherent cell types. The novel polymer brush architectures on the culture surface reduced protein adsorption and allowed efficient hydration to release the strongly adherent cells. Addition of functionalities to polymer brush architectures increased the adhesive strength of the surfaces for the culture of weakly adherent cell types and for anchoring mature cell sheets needed for cell sheet engineering applications. Thus, with the completion of this project, ISurTec will offer to the market a complete array of cell cultureware, thereby expanding the thermo-responsive technology to a wide variety of industrial, pharmaceutical and tissue engineering applications. We are confident that the manufacture friendly process to create novel brush polymer thermo-responsive surfaces can be successfully scaled up in the Phase II part of the project. In summary, the technical development allows efficient thermo-responsive cell attachment and release of a broad variety of cell types. The two specialized thermo-responsive surfaces will meet the non-invasive cell culture needs of a variety of applications in the fields of tissue engineering, cell therapy and drug discovery. Thus, clinical and pharmaceutical applications of cell types which were previously considered impossible, can be realized. Future developments in cell therapy and stem cell technologies combined with a full toolbox of thermo-responsive formats tailored for different types of cells, promises great benefits for human health and welfare.
